III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section
Description
1

(1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth's
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns with how a staff member was communicating
with youth at the facility. At times, the staff member would use
profanity. On one occasion, another staff member could hear the
staff member yelling at a youth in the classroom two doors down
in an intense manner.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was contacted on August 22, 2025, and did not
have any additional information.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
28, 2025. Youth A reported he has been placed at Clarence
Fischer Center for about six months. Youth A said he sees
Program Director “almost daily”, noting she will often sit in group
with them. Youth A said he thinks Program Director is “a good
woman” and is a positive influence on him. Youth A denied ever
seeing Program Director cuss, ridicule, or threaten youth. Youth A
said he was not on a unit with Youth D however, was in school
with him. Youth A denied ever seeing Program Director have
inappropriate communication with Youth D.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
28, 2025. Youth B reported he has been placed at Clarence
Fischer Center for about three weeks. Youth B said he has seen
Program Director “around” and does not have any concerns with
the way in which she interacts with him or any other youth. Youth
B denied ever seeing Program Director yell, curse, or threaten any
youth.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
28, 2025. Youth C reported he has been placed at Clarence
Fischer Center for about seven months. Youth C said he sees
Program Director “almost daily” noting she conducted his family
therapy sessions. Youth C said he does not have any concerns
about the way in which Program Director interacts with him or
other youth. Youth C said he has not seen Program Director yell or
2

curse at youth. Youth C said he was present at school when
Program Director interacted with Youth D. Youth C said Youth D
was “always disrespecting staff” and had sent an inappropriate
email to Program Director, so she came into the classroom and
“set him straight”. Youth C described the interaction as Program
Director using a louder, firm tone “like a mom would” to tell Youth
D he needed to “act and do better”. Youth C said it was an
appropriate interaction and Program Director was “just trying to
get Youth D to act right”. Youth C said he does not have any
concerns about the way Program Director treats him or the other
youth.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at his current placement
on August 21, 2025, by DCWL Consultant. Youth D said he
remembered Program Director. Youth D stated he had a rough
start at Clarence Fischer Center (CFC). Youth D said on his
second day at CFC, Program Director yelled at him during group
about no fighting and no gangs. Youth D stated Program Director
used profanity and said, “I’m the head bitch in charge. If you don’t
want to do the program, I can take you back myself.” Youth D
stated he asked to speak with Program Director privately and did
so in the hallway. Youth D stated he told her that it wasn’t
appropriate for her to yell and that his mom barely yelled at him.
Youth D stated he got to know Program Director and she told him
and the youths that she didn’t grow up with love and had death
after death. Youth D stated he understands her story and how she
grew up on her own. Youth D stated he thought at first Program
Director had something against him, but he realized Program
Director wants the best for the youth and “she’s just hard on kids”
using “tough love.” Youth D stated he was escalated to his current
placement for fighting at CFC.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
28, 2025. Staff 1 said he has been employed at Wolverine Human
Services for ten months and has spent about eight of them at
Clarence Fischer Center. Staff 1 said Program Director comes on
the units a couple times a week. Staff 1 said Program Director
comes across as strict and stern to the youth. Staff 1 said when
she first started, she was “more gruff” in her interactions and has
since settled in and will talk to the youth in a “motherly tone”,
holding them accountable for their actions in an appropriate
manner. Staff 1 said he has not heard Program Director cursing at
youth or ridiculing them. Staff 1 said Program Director is always
positive and encourages the youth to try to get them to make
better choices and is never demeaning toward the youth. Staff 1
3

denied seeing Program Director yell at or have inappropriate
communication with Youth D.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
28, 2025. Staff 2 said he has been employed at Wolverine Human
Services for about three months and has been at Clarence
Fischer Center the entire time. Staff 2 said he sees Program
Director on the units interacting with the youth “several times a
week”. Staff 2 said she has never seen Program Director yelling,
cursing, or ridiculing youth. Staff 2 described her interactions as
an “elevated voice” at times but always done in a “professional
manner”. Staff 2 said Program Director “carries herself with
authority” which can be intimidating at first, but she always wants
what is best for the youth and the program. Staff 2 denied ever
seeing Program Director curse or yell at Youth D.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on August
28, 2025. Staff 3 said he has been working at Clarence Fischer
Center for a year or so but has been with the organization for
many years. Staff 3 said he sees Program Director on the units
about “every other week”. Staff 3 said he has never seen Program
Director interact inappropriately with Youth D or any other youth.
Staff 3 said Program Director will use an “elevated mom voice”
when speaking to the youth at times but it is always done
professionally. Staff 3 said Youth D sent an email to Program
Director threatening to kill her. She came to the classroom and
asked him why he sent it and told him it was inappropriate to send
threatening emails as it could get him into a lot of trouble if he sent
it to the wrong person. Staff 3 said Program Director is strict and
holds the youth accountable for their actions in order to try to help
them make better decisions.
Staff 4 was interviewed via telephone on September 3, 2025.
Staff 4 reported she worked at Clarence Fischer Center (CFC)
from November 2024 until August 2025. Staff 4 said she worked
second shift and is familiar with Youth D. Staff 4 said shortly after
Youth D was placed at CFC, he was having a “rough day” as he
was having difficulty adjusting to the placement and she heard
Program Director “screaming” at Youth D in the hallway outside of
unit one. Staff 4 said she was working on unit three which is on
the opposite end of the hallway and poked her head out of the
door to see what was happening. She heard Youth D say “bitch”
and Program Director respond saying, “I can be the biggest bitch”.
Staff 4 said Program Director then made a comment about being
able to move Youth D back to detention if he did not like the CFC
program. Staff 4 said she never saw Program Director interact
4

with youth on her unit but said she would “yell at youth in general”
and that it was “tough love” she was giving to the youth. Staff 4
noted Staff 5, Staff 6, Staff 7, and Staff 8 were also working the
shift when Program Director was yelling at Youth D in the hallway.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on September 17, 2025.
Staff 5 said he has worked at Clarence Fischer Center (CFC) for
about sixteen years and is currently on second shift. Staff 5 said
he has seen Program Director interact with youth often both in
passing as well as addressing youth in group settings. Staff 5 said
Program Director is “firm” when speaking to youth and will point
out what the youth are doing “wrong and right” within the program.
Staff 5 said some youth will become upset when Program Director
is addressing them because they do not want to be “called out”,
clarifying she only points out group behaviors and does not single
out one youth. Staff 5 said he believes the redirection from
Program Director comes from “a good place”, making several
statements such as “she wants the boys to change and become
better”, “she tries to give them a wake-up call because she cares”,
she is “trying to save their lives”, and “she is all in and does not
tolerate BS”. Staff 5 said Program Director is never disrespectful,
demeaning, or verbally abusive when communicating with the
youth. Staff 5 said he worked many shifts with Youth D and said
he came into the program “bucking the system” and would argue
with all the staff and Program Director about all of the program
expectations. Staff 5 described Program Director’s relationship
with Youth D as “bumpy” because she is firm and sets
expectations and Youth D did not like that. Staff 5 said he never
saw Program Director communicate inappropriately with Youth D,
denying her cussing at him or threatening him. Staff 5 said all staff
have areas to work on and her approach could be “different with
certain kids” but noted she also is the director so needs to have
the respect of the youth.
Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone on September 25, 2025.
Staff 6 said he works second shift at Clarence Fischer Center and
has seen Program Director interact with youth on many occasions,
normally in a group setting. Staff 6 said he does not have any
concerns with the way in which Program Director communicates
with the youth, describing her as an authority figure that sets the
rules and expectations for the youth to follow. Staff 6 denied
seeing any individual interactions between Program Director and
Youth D.
Staff 7 was interviewed via telephone on September 25, 2025.
Staff 7 said he works second shift at Clarence Fischer Center and
5

has seen Program Director interact with the youth during his
shifts. Staff 7 said Program Director will address the youth as a
group and hold them accountable when they are not following
expectations of the program. Staff 7 said Program Director will
speak to the youth with an elevated voice but said it was not
yelling. Staff 7 denied hearing Program Director cursing at the
youth or calling them names or threatening them. Staff 7 said he
did not have any concerns with how Program Director
communicates with the youth. Staff 7 denied seeing Program
Director interact with Youth D individually, yell at him, or have any
inappropriate communication with him.
Staff 8 was interviewed via telephone on September 17, 2025.
Staff 8 said he works second shift at Clarence Fischer Center.
Staff 8 said he has seen Program Director interact with the youth
often and has never had any concerns about her being verbally
abusive towards them. Staff 8 denied Program Director ever
cursing at youth or getting in their space when talking with them.
Staff 8 said he has never seen or heard of Program Director
having individual interactions with Youth D. Staff 8 said Program
Director will typically address the whole group of youth if there are
any issues and will use a “stern voice that reminds me of my
mom” when talking to the youth. Staff 8 said Program Director’s
conversations always seem to “come from a good place, wanting
the boys to do better”. Staff 8 said he does not have any concerns
about Program Director’s interactions or communication with the
youth.
Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on September 3,
2025. Supervisor said he previously was a youth specialist at CFC
but was moved to Vassar House about two months ago.
Supervisor said while working at CFC he worked with Youth D.
Supervisor said he never witnessed Program Director yelling at
Youth D or any other youth. Supervisor said Youth D never
disclosed Program Director being verbally abusive towards him,
nor has any other youth. Supervisor said he overheard two staff
talking, he could not remember who, about a situation between
Program Director and Youth D where Youth D made a comment
like “even my mama don’t talk to me like that” and Program
Director saying something about “maybe she should”, however he
noted that he was not directly part of the conversation nor did he
hear this occur and was not exactly sure of the all the details or
context to what was being said in the conversation.
Program Director was interviewed via telephone on
September 17, 2025. Program Director said she interacts with the
6

Clarence Fischer Center youth everyday she is working. Program
Director said she will see the youth in passing, go for walks with
them during recreation time, address them during dinner, and
participate in group meetings. Program Director said she has
addressed the youth many times for negative behaviors, stating
this is typically done in a group setting and she rarely addresses
youth individually. Program Director described her behavior when
addressing the youth as “assertive” with an “elevated voice that is
not demeaning” similar to the way in which “a mother would
address a child”. Program Director said her redirection comes
from care and concern as she does not want these youth to
continue down the path they are on. Program Director said she
does not recall a time when she ever redirected Youth D. Program
Director said Youth D was a “lose cannon” and would “attack
youth and staff frequently”. Program Director said Youth D was not
in the program for very long as he was not a good fit. Program
Director said Youth D never called her a “bitch”. Program Director
said she never curses at the youth, including Youth D. Program
Director said there have been many times she has talked to the
whole group of youth about needing to be motivated to work the
program and if they do not feel it is a good fit for them or if they
are unwilling to follow program expectations to talk to her and she
will contact their case managers to help find them a better
program, but this was never specific to Youth D. Program
Manager said Youth D did make a comment after a group meeting
stating “my momma don’t even talk to me like that”, which
Program Manager said she later found out that Youth D and his
mother are more like “friends” and he did not have discipline in her
household. Program Manager denied making any statement to
Youth D after he made that statement. Program Manager denied
being verbally abusive towards the youth and said all her
redirection and interactions with them “come from a good place”
as she wants them to do good.
Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services Communication with Youth
Policy was reviewed. The policy states “All staff are
expected to communicate with recipients of care (clients) in
a professional manner. Communication not authorized by
the Agency will be interpreted as unprofessional, sexual,
predatory, and/or illegal. Specifically, staff should not swear
at, threaten, or communicate in any way that would violate
Child Protection Law.”
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, Program Director does not yell, threat, ridicule, or
verbally abuse the youth at Clarence Fisher Center.
7

Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
